2020-I-1.situation: When a triangle has two equal sides and two equal base angles, and you need to relate side lengths and angles.
2020-I-1.suggestion: Assign variables to the equal sides and base angles, and apply the Law of Cosines to relate unknown side lengths and angles.

2020-I-1.situation: When points are marked along triangle sides at distances equal to other sides or segments, leading to several equal-length segments.
2020-I-1.suggestion: Introduce variables for unknown segment positions (such as parameters along sides), set up coordinate expressions for all relevant points, and write equations expressing the given equal-length conditions.

2020-I-1.situation: When you have coordinates for points defined in terms of trigonometric functions of an angle, and need to equate distances between them.
2020-I-1.suggestion: Express all points in terms of the unknown angle using trigonometric identities, compute squared distances, and set up equations to solve for the angle.

2020-I-1.situation: When a trigonometric equation in cos(x) or sin(x) leads to a high-degree polynomial, and the angle is a rational multiple of π.
2020-I-1.suggestion: Recognize or search for minimal polynomials satisfied by cos(kπ/n) for small integers k, n, and match the polynomial to identify the angle.
